security_audit.summary: Legitimate website auditing tool. Static findings are false positives - scanner misidentified documentation examples and URL patterns as security threats. The skill uses network access for website crawling and external commands to invoke the squirrel CLI, which is expected and documented behavior.

high_findings.title: C2 Keywords Detected
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged 'C2' pattern in README.md. This is a false positive - the pattern appears in a CDN URL path (mintcdn.com/squirrelscan/...) for the project logo, not command-and-control malware communication.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: The flagged text is 'CCMTmLbI4xfnpJbQ' in a CDN URL - standard image hosting path, not C2 communication.

high_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm Flags
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged 'http' in URLs as weak crypto. This is a false positive - documentation references legitimate URLs including both http and https variants. The skill itself performs no cryptographic operations.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: URL references in documentation are not cryptographic implementations. Many URLs use https:// which is secure.

high_findings.title: Pipe to Shell Pattern
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged 'curl | bash' install pattern. This is legitimate software installation, documented in the skill as the official installation method from squirrelscan.com.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard install pattern from official project documentation. Users explicitly choose to run this install command.

high_findings.title: PowerShell Invocation
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged PowerShell install command for Windows. This is legitimate software installation documented in the skill.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard Windows installation method from official project documentation.

high_findings.title: Hidden File Access in Home Directory
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged ~/.local and ~/.squirrel paths. These are standard Linux user-space installation directories, not hidden credential files.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard user installation directories for application binaries and project configuration files.

medium_findings.title: Shell Backtick Execution in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Scanner detected backtick characters in documentation. These appear in XML code examples and command documentation, not actual shell execution code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks in XML declarations and code examples are documentation, not executable shell code.

medium_findings.title: Hidden File Access Patterns
medium_findings.description: Scanner flagged access to hidden directories (~/.squirrel). These are standard application data directories for the squirrelscan tool.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard application data directories documented in the skill for configuration and project storage.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URL References
low_findings.description: Documentation contains hardcoded URLs to official project resources. These are legitimate documentation and installation links.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation URLs to official project website and documentation. No external third-party dependencies.

content.user_title: Audit websites for SEO and security issues
content.value_statement: Website auditing is complex and time-consuming. The squirrelscan CLI automates comprehensive audits across 149+ rules covering SEO, performance, accessibility, and security, generating actionable reports for AI agents.
actual_capabilities: Crawl websites and analyze pages against 149+ audit rules
Generate health scores with category breakdowns (SEO, technical, content, security)
Detect broken links, missing meta tags, accessibility issues, and performance problems
Output LLM-optimized reports for AI-assisted debugging and fixes
Check for leaked secrets, security headers, and HTTPS usage
Audit against E-E-A-T guidelines and accessibility standards
limitations: Requires squirrel CLI to be installed and accessible in PATH
Cannot audit password-protected or authentication-required pages
Does not perform dynamic JavaScript rendering analysis beyond basic browser emulation
Audit speed depends on website size and server response times

use_cases.title: Debug technical SEO issues
use_cases.description: Analyze a website to identify and fix technical SEO problems like missing meta tags, broken links, and crawlability issues.

use_cases.title: Generate site health reports
use_cases.description: Run comprehensive audits that output health scores and actionable recommendations for improving website quality.

use_cases.title: Enable AI-powered website fixes
use_cases.description: Provide AI assistants with structured audit data to autonomously identify and suggest fixes for website issues.

output: Critical: Missing meta title on 2 pages (about, contact)
Warning: No Open Graph tags on homepage
Fix: Add <meta name="description"> to affected pages
- core/meta-title: Missing meta titles on 2 pages
Recommendations: Add unique titles to all pages

best_practices: Use --format llm for AI-optimized output that is 40% smaller than verbose formats
Run audits on live websites for accurate rendering and performance data
Save audit IDs to compare site health before and after changes
Use --max-pages limit for large sites to control crawl duration
anti_patterns: Do not use --format llm with the audit command directly (only with report)
Do not audit local development URLs expecting production-equivalent results
Do not skip --format llm when working with AI assistants (verbose output wastes tokens)
Do not forget to verify installation with squirrel --version before running audits

faq.question: What is the difference between squirrel audit and squirrel report?
faq.answer: The audit command crawls and analyzes a website, saving results to a database. The report command generates output from a previous audit. Use audit to start, then report to export results in different formats.

faq.question: Why should I use --format llm instead of other formats?
faq.answer: The LLM format is optimized for AI consumption - it is 40-70% smaller than verbose XML, reducing token usage while maintaining all structured data needed for analysis.

faq.question: How long does a typical website audit take?
faq.answer: Audit time depends on site size and server response time. Small sites (10-50 pages) complete in seconds. Large sites (200+ pages) may take several minutes. Use --verbose to see progress.

faq.question: What audit rules are checked?
faq.answer: The squirrelscan CLI checks 149+ rules across 20 categories including SEO, technical, performance, content, security, accessibility, E-E-A-T, crawlability, and schema validation.

faq.question: Can I audit password-protected pages?
faq.answer: The basic audit does not support authentication. For password-protected content, ensure the site allows guest access or use staging environments with similar content.

faq.question: How do I compare audit results over time?
faq.answer: Each audit gets a unique ID. Run audits, save the IDs, then use report with different IDs to compare health scores and issue counts between audits.
